metadata.title: Anomia, Degenerative
anatomical location body part affected: Anterior and inferolateral temporal lobes of the brain;(1) involvement of the left hippocampal region has also been documented(2)
description: Degenerative anomia is a primary symptom of semantic dementia (SD), a type of frontotemporal dementia in which patients have poor semantic memory but relatively intact episodic memory.(2) Degenerative anomia is also a symptom of primary progressive aphasia (PPA). PPA is a degenerative form of aphasia associated with atrophy of the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain.(29) There are three clinical subtypes of PPA: nonfluent/agrammatic variant PPA, semantic variant PPA, and logopenic variant PPA.(29) The primary symptom of logopenic PPA is deficits in word retrieval (i.e., anomia).(29) For detailed information on frontotemporal dementia, see Clinical Review…Dementia, Frontotemporal ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708948. Patients with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) might exhibit degenerative anomia in conjunction with more global memory deficits (for detailed information about AD, see Clinical Review…Alzheimer’ s Disease: Speech Therapy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708913).(2) Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) sometimes exhibit anomia associated with disease progression (for detailed information about MS, see Clinical Review…Multiple Sclerosis:Communication Deficits ; CINAHL Topic ID: T708856)(36)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified. In order to qualify for reimbursement, treatment programs must be considered medically necessary and the clinician should anticipate that improvement is possible through therapy. Treatment studies offer preliminary evidence that treatment might slow the progression of degenerative anomia over time and is most beneficial in the early stages of the underlying disease.(1) Once comprehension deficits become more pronounced and episodic memory is affected, treatment to restore word knowledge becomes less feasible(1)
presentation signs and symptoms: The patient exhibits a loss of conceptual and word form knowledge with progressive difficulty retrieving or pronouncing words needed for communication.(3,4)Word-finding  difficulties vary and often lead to difficulties expressing thoughts, understanding the meaning of spoken or written words, or naming objects that he/she is shown.(5) Errors on confrontation naming tasks include omission errors, coordinate errors (e.g., “mouse” for “cat”), and superordinate errors (e.g., “animal” for “fox”).(1)Word-finding  difficulties might also manifest as circumlocutions (“We went to the place to get gas” –filling station). As the anomia progresses, the patient might exhibit frequent pauses and semantic paraphasias (substitution of semantically related but incorrect words; e.g., “chair” for “sofa”).(1) In advanced stages, the patient might also exhibit pronounced comprehension difficulties and/or face and object recognition deficits (prosopagnosia and associative agnosia).(1) (For detailed information on assessment and treatment of agnosia, see Clinical Review…Agnosia ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708855) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: It is important to have a family member or caregiver available to provide information when the patient is not able to communicate. Depression is common among persons with dementia and can adversely affect test performance.(9) Speech-language  pathologists (SLPs) should be knowledgeable about symptoms of depression (e.g., loss of interest in daily activities, problems sleeping, feelings of sadness and hopelessness) and refer to a neuropsychologist or clinical psychologist when signs are present.(9) The time of day and the number of previous evaluations can affect the patient’s alertness and performance. During the evaluation, it is of utmost importance to be aware of a patient’s level of fatigue, pain tolerance, and level of frustration

pathogenesis: SD is commonly associated with a focal degeneration of the temporal neocortex.(7) Patient exhibits signs of decreasedblood flow and decreased glucose utilization within the atrophied areas.(5) AD is sometimes also associated withdegenerative anomia(1)

In a study conducted in the United States with 15 patients with PPA, researchers found that progressive atrophy of the leftand right middle temporal cortex and the left angular gyrus correlated with reduced auditory word comprehension overtime. At any given point in time, errors of auditory word comprehension were associated with atrophy of the bilateraltemporal poles, the inferior temporal cortex, and the left middle temporal cortex(27)

In a study conducted in Australia on degenerative anomia in 23 individuals with amnestic AD and 22 individuals withPPA (with assumed underlying AD pathology), researchers investigated the areas of brain atrophy associated withdegenerative anomia. All of the participants had auditory comprehension deficits; expressive deficits included phonologicalsubstitutions, semantic paraphasias, and abnormal repetitions of single words. Researchers found that degenerative anomiawas associated with thinning in the left superior temporal gyrus in both groups of participants; however, anomia was alsocorrelated with thinning in the right inferior temporal regions in the participants with amnestic AD (AD in which theprimary deficit is memory impairment). Deficits in word comprehension were associated with bilateral cortical thinningof the fusiform gyri in both participant groups. Researchers concluded that language deficits in AD and PPA result fromimpairments of semantic, lexical, and phonological processing(37)

The concurrent use of multiple medications is common among older adults who have complex medical conditions, and the side effects of these medications can adversely affect cognitive and communicative functioning.(9) Contact a pharmacist or physician regarding questions about medication side effects(9)

relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Note use of an AAC device, including pen/paper –If patient is not using an AAC device, it is appropriate during the evaluation to assess his or her ability to use AAC  –Assess the patient’s ability to point to named pictures and use a letter board to spell out words –For detailed information on the use of AAC as part of a treatment plan for patients with degenerative anomia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicIf speech difficulties are detected, perform an oral mechanism exam (e.g., structure and function) and note any difficulties in articulation. A motor speech evaluation should be performed if there are signs of coexisting apraxia and/or dysarthria (see Clinical Review…Apraxia of Speech (Acquired) ; CINAHL Topic IDT708586and the series of Clinical Reviews on dysarthria)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Screening for vision and hearing should always precede evaluation for dementia, anomia, or aphasia. An audiologist should check for impacted cerumen prior to pure-tone audiometric screening and word recognition testing.(9) Informal assessment of vision is required if patient intends to support communication with visual methods (e.g., writing, gestures, pictures)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: The following are examples of assessments that can be used with adults who have degenerative anomia. In addition to a comprehensive language evaluation, measures of episodic memory should be administered if dementia is suspected. Both formal and informal measures should be included to determine performance on daily living skills.(1) When selecting tests, clinicians must consider the cultural and linguistic background of the patient and determine if the measurement was standardized on the relevant population.(9) Tests that have normative information onTest consists of 60 items to measure confrontation naming ability from line drawings. Items are ranked in their ability to be named, and results will indicate severity of anomia along a continuum(13)To assess a person's ability to name or point to a named picture and the nature of a naming deficit (e.g., difficulty retrieving semantic information from pictures, words, or print; difficulty retrieving the appropriate spoken form of a word).(14) Pyramids and Palm Trees Test is a cross-culturally  valid assessment of nonverbal object semantics for patients with PPA that provides clinically appropriate results(23)A questionnaire-style  assessment that researchers developed specifically to assess speech and language abilities in PPA.(32) The results of the questionnaire are used to guide a formalized interview with the patient (and caregiver when appropriate and necessary) and to help with treatment planning(32)
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: A comprehensive communication evaluation should determine –Confrontation naming ability -Phonological errors are common in naming tasks among patients with degenerative anomia(30) –Auditory short-term  memory –Nonverbal reasoning –Repetition of words/phrases and sentences –Auditory comprehension –Expressive language ability -Expressive language in patients with degenerative anomia is marked by a slow rate of speech as a result of word-finding difficulties(29) -Obtain a speech sample by asking the patient to provide a narrative or tell a story (e.g., “Tell me the story of Cinderella.” “Tell me about your family.”) Patients with SD typically speak more slowly and use words that are shorter and higher in frequency and familiarity (i.e., more common) than neurologically intact adults(25) -Expressive grammatical errors are common in patients with PPA (e.g., “speaked” for “spoke”)(34) –Reading –Writing
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Refer to psychological and cognitive evaluations to assist in informing course of treatment and providing a prognosis for therapy. The following are examples of tests used to(11) To assess intellectual and cognitive abilities of adults(12) To assess cognitive status of adults. Sections include Orientation to Time, Orientation to Place, Attention and Calculation, Recall, Naming, Repetition, Comprehension, Reading, Writing, and Drawing
relevant tests and measures.swallow examination: Complete a swallowing examination as indicated. Patients with degenerative anomia might have coexisting dysphagia. For detailed information on dysphagia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on dysphagia
relevant tests and measures.tracheostomy examination: If present, assess tracheostomy tube and document date of placement, current respiratory status, and use of speaking valve. other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regards to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Inform patient and family/caregivers of the potential for falls and educate about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

The relative benefits and risks of intensive therapy should be evaluated on a case-by-case  basis. Authors of a case study of a patient with degenerative anomia indicated that regular practice and self-assessment  of word-finding  abilities resulted in a hyperawareness of the progressive nature of the anomia and led to task obsession and feelings of frustration and depression.(15) To ensure relevance and appropriateness of treatment programs, decisions about goals and course of therapy should be made in collaboration with the patient, caregivers, and other healthcare professionals.(9) The patient’s cultural background, language preference, and interests must also be considered when designing a treatment program.(9) Treatment goals and objects will shift with the progression of the disease(1)

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The clinical diagnosis of SD is made when language is the only area of progressive dysfunction within the first 2 years of the disease. Brain imaging typically indicates atrophy rather than a specific lesion. Memory for daily events, visual spatial skills, nonverbal problem-solving  skills, reasoning, and social skills show no major deficits in the first 2 years of the disease.(5) Diagnosis is made by the neurologist with input from SLP and other professionals treating the patient To select the appropriate approach for treatment, the SLP will benefit from knowledge of cognitive models of word production to assist in identifying the underlying deficit (e.g., phonological knowledge, semantic knowledge).(3) Most models of word production recognize a semantic level, a phonological level, and a component that transmits information between the two levels. Different errors result from disruption to various parts of the system, and treatment should be designed to target these specific deficits. Patients with degenerative anomia typically have the most difficulty with conceptual and semantic knowledge, and strategies such as phonemic cueing rarely are beneficial(4)
assessment plan of care.rule out: The clinician should differentiate degenerative anomia from progressive dysarthria, apraxia, and phonological disintegration in which the formation (articulation) rather than the usage of words becomes disrupted.(5) Patients with AD might also exhibit degenerative anomia but have additional, more severe impairments in memory and behavior. Core memory functions that are impaired in AD remain largely preserved in SD.(5) At present, there are no studies outlining different treatment approaches for degenerative anomia for patients with AD versus for patients with SD
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Standardized neuropsychological testing by a neuropsychologist can detect SD in its early stages. Refer to OT for assistance with daily living skills if appropriate
treatment summary: Errorless learning and effortful (active) learning approach:  Treatment is considered “errorless” if it avoids the production of incorrect responses and learning of incorrect associations. It can be “effortful” (active) in its use of higher-level  cognitive function in describing and priming target words –Researchers who conducted a multiple baseline design study in the United States explored the use of errorless and effortful learning on ability to name 40 photo stimuli (20 objects/20 actions) for 3 subjects with progressive aphasia. In 9–12  treatment sessions over a 2- to 3-month  period (2-hour  sessions), subjects were told to avoid naming the object or action during stimulus presentation. Instead, they were engaged in a facilitated conversation about the target’s conceptual, semantic, and/or phonological features with the purpose of priming them to remember the word. Short-term  gains were noted in naming of nouns by all subjects, but after 6 months 2 of the 3 subjects had lost all gain on naming trained nouns and generalization to untrained nouns(16) –In a study conducted in the United Kingdom, researchers compared errorless and errorful therapy approaches for object-naming  training in patients with AD(17) -Subjects were 8 patients with a diagnosis of mild AD -Both errorless and errorful therapy approaches were used concurrently with separate word lists of 20 objects for each therapy approach -In the errorless approach, the subjects were given the target word in spoken and written forms by the clinician and asked to repeat 3 times while looking at a picture of the object; in the errorful approach, the subjects were guided to the correct word through a progression of phonemic and orthographic cues -Intervention lasted for 10 sessions (2 times per week/5 weeks) with 40–60  minute sessions -Outcomes were assessed at 1 and 5 weeks post therapy and measured according to the percentage of objects named correctly -Baseline: All three-word  lists (control set, errorless approach, and errorful approach) were named with less than 10% accuracy -1 week post therapy -Control: 15% correct -Errorless learning approach: 45% correct -Errorful approach: 48% correct -5 weeks post therapy -Control: 15% correct -Errorless learning approach: 35% correct -Errorful approach: 38% correct -The object lists included in either the errorless learning or errorful learning approach were both named with significantly more accuracy than were the objects on the control list; there was not a significant difference between the two therapeutic approaches –Researchers who conducted a study in Canada compared four different methods of treatment for word relearning in patients with SD(18) -Seven individuals with SD were the subjects in this study -Four methods of treatment compared in the study were errorless-passive  (EL-P),  errorless-active  (EL-A), errorful-passive (EF-P),  and errorful-active (EF-A) -EL-P:  cues/names of objects were provided without giving the subject an opportunity to make an error -EL-A:  subjects answered questions about cues and objects without having an opportunity to make an error -EF-P:  cues and erroneous names were given by the clinician and the participant was allowed the opportunity to make errors  -EF-A:  subjects answered questions about cues and objects and were allowed the opportunity to make errors -Treatment took place over 8–12  weeks in 24 sessions, and 8 different word lists were used across the different treatment conditions -Outcomes were measured as a percentage of pictures named correctly and were taken immediately post treatment and 1 and 3 months post treatment -As a group, the patients all showed significant improvement from baseline in object naming with intervention; although there was a stronger treatment effect with EL-A  treatment, percentage of correctly named pictures was not significantly higher than the other three methods -Both treatment and maintenance effects were stronger for individuals who had preserved auditory comprehension skills

Computer-based  intervention:  A computer program can be used to provide cueing, feedback, and visual support for patients relearning words –In a multiple-baseline  study conducted in Canada, researchers tested the effectiveness of one treatment program, MossTalk Words, with 2 subjects with progressive aphasia. Subjects were trained on three lists of 15 words until they reached criterion level. Orthographic cues and full word cues were provided during the intervention phase. Subjects were tested immediately post treatment and 1 month afterwards. Results indicated that subjects achieved and maintained significant improvement on two of the three word lists(19) –Authors of a case study from Canada combined an errorless learning approach with the MossTalk Words software for treatment of degenerative anomia associated with SD(20) -Multiple-baseline  design; treatment sessions were 3 times per week for 1 hour each; principles of errorless learning were combined with MossTalk Words software to train the patient on 3 lists of 20 words each -Within 4 months, the patient relearned 41 of 60 trained words; knowledge of these words was maintained after 3 months. The patient’s word knowledge improved on untrained items as well; however, the percentage was not statistically significant –Orthographic treatment: Authors of a case study with a 69-year-old  bilingual Norwegian-English  speaking woman with PPA reported naming improvements in untreated items in both languages after being treated with an orthographic treatment. The computer program used in this case study involved having the patient see a picture alone, a word alone, and then paired word-picture  stimuli. The patient was cued by the computer to copy the words she had seen on a sheet of paper and then was given examples of correct and incorrect word pairings and asked to state “yes” or “no” if the pairings were accurate(35)

Self-study  of picture dictionaries and other resources (word-picture  matching):  Authors of a case study from the United Kingdom examining the effects of self-study  and verbal rehearsal of word-picture  matches in sets of semantic categories (30 min/day) indicated short-term  gains on fluency naming of practiced categories but a decline after termination of daily intensive training.(15) Researchers discussed the inherently “errorless learning” aspect of this treatment and its benefits

Meaningful contextual link/autobiographical association:  Personal references and descriptions (e.g., “dog”: “Your dog is named Maddie. She is a Labrador.”) are explicitly taught for each target word during treatment with the rationale that these meaningful links will strengthen retention ability. Authors of a case study from the United Kingdom indicated that the words that were taught with meaningful and personal information were better retained than words that were taught using impersonal definitions. Retention of target words 250 days after treatment was 50%.(7) In another study conducted in the United Kingdom, researchers examined the relationship between personal familiarity with words and retention ability and found that autobiographical experience did not lead to greater retention of words.(21) The authors suggested that retention may be dependent on both “concept frequency” (number of times an object or concept is encountered) and “concept quality” (the richness of the underlying semantic representation and amount of knowledge of an item)(6)

Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) : tDCS involves painless, noninvasive stimulation of the brain with direct electrical current. Current is applied through electrodes on the head. Although showing promise in research studies, brain stimulation is not widely available for clinical use as a treatment for aphasia(24) –In a study conducted in the United States with 6 patients with PPA, researchers combined either tDCS or a sham treatment plus spelling intervention in a within-subject crossover study. Results showed improvement in spelling on the trained items for both tDCS and sham treatments; however, significant improvement on spelling of untrained items was observed only in the tDCS condition(24)  . maintenance or prevention: Treatment studies offer preliminary evidence that treatment might slow the progression of degenerative anomia over time and is most beneficial at the early stages of the underlying disease (within the first 2 years).(1) Clinic-based  treatment should eventually be transferred to home-based routines so that the patient and caregivers can continue therapeutic activities independently
patient education: Patient and family/caregiver education should include information about the effects of degenerative anomia and the progression of disease. When possible, the patient’s family or caregiver should be educated about facilitative techniques to use when assisting the patient with communication
